subject: Re: [junit] Testing Abstract Classes
msgSnippet: ... Ditto. Here is mine:  an adapter is a class implementing with empty bodies some of or all the methods of an interface.  You can extend Adapters when you
messageBody:
On 3/12/06, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > A stateless abstract class is usually a Strategy, so I'd rather use it
> > than extend it.
>
> Meaning you'd rather declare it as an interface?
>
> > One exception is the empty Strategy, otherwise known as
> > an Adapter.
>
> That's a different definition of Adapter than I'm used to (or a
> different application).


Ditto.

Here is mine: an adapter is a class implementing with empty bodies some of
or all the methods of an interface. You can extend Adapters when you only
want to implement a few methods of an interface but not all of them.

What's your definition, JB?

--
Cédric
http://testng.org


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
